newsitem.title: USA: DSP shares off on merger news.
newsitem.headline: DSP shares off on merger news.

text.p: Shares of DSP Communications Inc fell nearly 33 percent on Tuesday in reaction to the company's announced $400 million merger with Proxim Inc reflecting concerns that DSP may have too much.
Industry analysts said DSP was also hurt by fears the stock deal might be dilutive to earnings, something DSP officials denied.
DSP stock tumbled $17.125 to $35.25, while Proxim's shares rose $2-51/64 to $21.50.

Under the terms of the deal, Proxim shareholders will get 0.70 of a DSP common share for each Proxim share. The deal values Proxim at $36.66 per share, based on Monday's closing price, well above the current price. During a conference call with analysts and investors, DSP officials were questioned about the valuation.

"I don't understand why you felt you need to pay such a premium (for Proxim) and that's what DSP shareholders are quite disturbed," said one institutional investor. "It's not clear why you should pay a price that is double the price of the stock for a deal that would hopefully be synergistic and not immediately so.
Company officials said they were confident the merger would be non-dilutive to earnings.

"Analysts estimate that it will be five percent dilutive" in 1997, said DSP chief executive Nathan Hod at an industry conference in Monterey. "Knowing what analysts don't know about DSP, I believe this deal will not be dilutive."
Several analysts said the sell-off was an overreaction.
"This is a great story from a long-term perspective," said Robert Kaimowitz, analyst with Unterberg Harris.
"I believe it could be marginally dilutive in 1997, but could easily be accretive by 1998 and 1999."
